entry.title: Proposed work plan for 2015
entry.summary:
Alternative versions: LabNotebook, nbviewer, slideviewer, pdf

Table of Contents

  • Proposed Work Plan 2015-2016
    • Overview
    • Notebook Setup
    • Topics
    • Notes
      • Small-Big networks
      • Modes
    • TVB-SPM+DCM - detailed

    • Bibtex
    • Graveyard
    • Workdocs Conversion
    • Copy to blog dir and make entry
    • Styling

Overview¶

This is a preliminary, proposed, work plan for the next few months, starting mid June 2015. At this point it is entirely subject to major or complete revision, pending discussions, advice, recommendations, and clarifications of research priorities. The main emphasis - integrating TVB and SPM+DCM modelling methodologies and research programs, is nevertheless a topic we've already discussed and, I believe, have agreed is of both mutual and scientific interest.

So, the primary purpose of this document is to think through this set of research directions in detail, from scientific, methodological, and pragmatic perspectives.

The secondary purpose is to draw links to a number of other research directions that I think would be worth pursuing, including the relationship between circumscribed neural systems / cognitive networks and whole brain dynamics, modelling of cognitive activation topographies, and (eigen) modes of activity and connectivity [1].

It seemed best to open with the broader discussion first, however, and so the next few sections expand fairly concisely on these additional research directions and how they relate each other and to the core set of proposals. After that, I get into the finer details of what a tvb-spm+dcm research project would look like, and what we would hope to get from it.

Again, this is all up for discussion and both constructive and destructive critique. The more of all of these the better.

Topics¶

  • tvb-dcm
  • big/small/embedded networks
  • topographies
  • modes
  • cognitive networks
  • conduction delays + microstructure

Notes¶

Small-Big networks¶

  • the small-big network thing is at risk of being too focused on DCM/SPM methodology, rather than 'real science questions'
  • ...to broaden it out, can think about 'cognitive systems' in terms of small / embedded networks. This generalizes the question and makes it much more important: every textbook, and most neuroscience research, focuses on specific systems in isolation. So we are speaking to a much broader audience in that case
  • ...this starts to move towards the questions of cognitive network / activation topographies, which is another area I want to explore
  • key points here will be Deco and people on resting state network topographies, and I think UCL Tom on language network topographies with TVB
  • also could move toward 'hybrid' (both biophysical + cognitive, like e.g. Tim Behrens, Friston? ; and biophysical 'large' + biophysical 'small', like e.g. Cliff Kerr?)
  • ...perhaps then think about going to nengo workshop next year with ideas about integration

Modes¶

  • Robinson stuff
  • Robinson PRE paper links to DCM...
  • Multivariate analysis links to McIntosh stuff (?)

TVB-SPM+DCM - detailed¶

  • lots of things
  • delays; multiple routes;
  • possible paper strucutres / abstracts
  • estimation vs. 'reality'

Timeline¶

  • June 15-August 15
    • test + compare TVB Zetterberg Jansen and SPM David model
    • compile DCM + SPM literature review, summarizing options for extending literature publications
    • develop small/big/embedded network modelling methodology + concepts
    • pilot studies of some study replications
    • design structure of study(s) / paper(s)
  • August 15 - Oct 15
    • run + analyze selected simulations wrt selected core questions
    • get results!
  • Oct 15-Christmas
    • collate study results; design + write paper; plan for next

Footnotes¶

  • [1] This excludes other areas I am also interested in pursuing but don't directly relate to the issues at hand - including amongst other things ageing, white matter microstructure, and conduction delays. So just flagging those here for completeness.
